Let‚Äôs roll on to series 16.

A 4-day week with travelling and socialising, so I‚Äôm feeling tired. Buzzing about Design System Day next week though, it‚Äôs gonna be a blast.

What did I do this week?

  • Caught up with one of our delivery managers, who came back from holiday
  • Met the other leads on the team to discuss a move away from traditional Scrum
  • Contributed to speaker biographies and session information being on separate pages on the Design System website
  • Ran the fortnightly team reflection session
  • Sketched out a narrative for the Design System team showcase at Design System Day
  • Refined the epic for Show password, a new component we‚Äôre adding to the design system
  • Shuffled along some pull requests on the new Task List component and pattern
  • Joined the discussion on getting rid of the Experimental tag
  • Collaborated on publishing a standardised format for collecting evidence, so it‚Äôs easier for service teams to share research findings with us
  • Had a check-in with our senior management team
  • Asked speakers to send their slides for day 1 over to us
  • Caught up on the latest in our accessibility strategy
  • Tested out Hopin, which we‚Äôre using for day 2
  • Met with customer success folks at Slack to talk about how we use cross-government Slack (and how our team need more features)
  • Ran through the plans for day 1 and day 2 of Design System Day
  • Started preparing the slides for the Design System team showcase at Design System Day
  • Sketched out the roadmap for Q3

Tracking work

Of the 7 goals I set this week, I achieved 1 goal, progressed 3 goals, and didn‚Äôt start 3 other goals. Although it feels like a failure, when I look at the work I did do, almost half of the 20 tasks I did this week were all related to Design System Day. That was the right thing to work on, so really I was overambitious with the variety of work I‚Äôd be able to achieve this week.

I‚Äôm also taking some work into the weekend, so it‚Äôs clear I didn‚Äôt prioritise the right work for the week. Having said that, if I‚Äôd dropped the Q3 roadmap work for more time on Design System Day, I‚Äôd be worried about what we‚Äôre going to do after DS Day ‚Äì but now I‚Äôm not.

Tell you what, tracking my work like this and having a feedback loop to see whether I did the right stuff or not is working well.

Moving away from Scrum

Our delivery manager pitched this as a move away from the 2-week cycle to 4-week cycle, with 1 of those weeks as a reflection and planning week. It should give more time and space for planning ‚Äì sketching out how we‚Äôll tackle a piece of work and the skills needed ‚Äì and continuous improvement ‚Äì collaborating on changes to our ways of working.

It‚Äôs a good suggestion, as we don‚Äôt spend nearly enough time planning work and discussing process improvements as we should. I‚Äôve spent more time on elaboration and planning in teams outside of GDS, and you had to adapt ways of working every cycle at the startup, so I was adapting our playbook every week.

I think there‚Äôs room to adapt some other aspects of our ways of working, mainly a move to the team pitching work rather than being recipients of work requests. The Betting Table, where people pitch work, is how we might do this but one of our developers shared a similar process from Valve.

No doubt we‚Äôll work on this more in November, so keep an eye out for developments in my weeknotes. (You can also subscribe by email or RSS, check the footer at the bottom of my site.)

Data in Slack

There‚Äôs key data about our community and engagement in Slack, but we don‚Äôt have access to it. This sucks as we need those metrics, it all feeds in to our community strategy: how we make the community a key actor in iterating and evolving the GOV.‚ÄåUK Design System.

There‚Äôs two options: get more data from cross-government Slack or splinter off and create our own workspace. We‚Äôd rather not do the latter and there are switching costs for the community who already use cross-government Slack. But luckily CDDO is trialling paying for cross-gov Slack to see whether it‚Äôs valuable, and I‚Äôve been able to liaise with the customer success folks at Slack who can empathise with what we‚Äôre trying to do.

I suspect we wouldn‚Äôt have to do this if the Communications and Engagement functions hadn‚Äôt been shrunk so drastically by previous deputy directors, but there you go. It‚Äôs still ludicrous to me that an organisation building digital products and services, and trying to grow those products and services, doesn‚Äôt have enough people doing digital marketing. You can build whatever you want, but if no one knows about it no one will use it.

So, anyway, putting the rant aside, Slack are going to send us the aggregated data we need and look at giving us access to it too. I‚Äôll be setting some OKRs with our community designer at the end of the month, as part of our community strategy (which is also part of our growth strategy), and many of the key results will use data from Slack as indicators or input metrics.

Running

I‚Äôm in Shrewsbury for a half-marathon on Sunday. Haven‚Äôt done as much running this week as I‚Äôd have liked, but just going to trust that all the training I did for the marathon is still hanging around.

My A goal is to finish in under 1 hour 40 minutes, my B goal is to beat my previous personal best of 1 hour 51 minutes, and my C goal under 2 hours.

Not-drinking

Now that the marathon is out of the way, I‚Äôve been enjoying the odd tipple here and there. After months off the booze, you can definitely feel how tired and sluggish alcohol makes you.

I have found old behaviours creeping back that I‚Äôd like to nix. After attending lightning talks on AI safety on Thursday, I walked to the train station drinking a can. It breaks an emergent rule of only drinking with other people. I‚Äôll write more about this, other rules have emerged too.

items.content_text: Writing these weeknotes on Friday but shan‚Äôt be able to publish until early next week. Maybe I should move the hosting back to GitHub Pages. Although who am I kidding? Instead I‚Äôll do the complicated, toilful thing and set up something I need to maintain.What did I get up to this (last) week?  Wrote a short description of what we do and where we‚Äôre going for GOV.‚ÄåUK Design System job adverts  Caught up with a product manager who worked at MOJ but recently joined GDS  Said hello to a new team member  Shuffled along some issues on GitHub  Prepared a volunteers‚Äô guide for Design System Day  Published a code of conduct  Wrote and sent off follow-up questions for the service assessment from last week  Gathered willing participants for updating the product management learning list  Met with Ethan to go through the questions for our fireside talk  Published the programme of speakers and sessions for Design System Day 2023  Went to a great product community session with Randy Silver  Other stuff I didn‚Äôt make a note ofTracking workThis week I completed 25 tasks, although there‚Äôs a few I didn‚Äôt note down. Only 8 unplanned tasks this week. That means most of my time was spent on planned tasks. That matches up with my achievement rate of 87.5% this week ‚Äì I achieved 7 out of 8 weekly goals!A few weeks ago I set my goals for the month, and I added to that list over the month, so I set 12 goals in total. I achieved 6 of those goals, an achievement rate of 50%, and I progressed 3 goals. So a lot of the work I did this month contributed to the goals I had set for the projects I‚Äôm working on. Nice.There were 3 goals I didn‚Äôt start but, to be fair, I descoped those based on a roadmap change. So I‚Äôm happy with not getting those done.Pretty sure I‚Äôm working on the right things. Unplanned work always crops up for product managers, but there was less of it last week. So I‚Äôm still spending the majority of my time on things that move the needle. Pretty happy with the achievement rate of monthly goals too. The high priority stuff got done.Might calculate how much time I spend on TeamOps, curious to know whether it‚Äôs a big portion of time.Design System Day 2023Everything‚Äôs starting to slot in to place with this now. It has been planned in detail and that‚Äôs paying off, all the major priority tasks have been done. We‚Äôve got to do some training on Hopin for the second day of the conference, but that‚Äôll chime nicely with a test run of the plan for both days.It‚Äôs always the same with running events. Everything seems manic and stressful in the run up, but the planning always pays off. I‚Äôve been reminding the team that we‚Äôve got the major stuff done so the conference is almost already a confirmed success. It‚Äôs still worth reserving a little energy for adapting to last-minute changes on the day though.I‚Äôm trying not to get too busy on other things so I can be a backstop for any big-effort tasks, but it‚Äôs all going well so far.Agile governance and communicationsAt the product community session, I asked Randy a question about tactics for agile governance and communication as organisations scale. Show & tells and blogging filled this purpose at GDS in the early days, but 10 years later things haven‚Äôt really changed.If anything, the blogging has dried up compared to the early proliferation of many posts per week. There‚Äôs internal weeknotes but these are bullet points that don‚Äôt capture the context or detail of our deep work. And senior management and leadership is too busy to come to show & tells, they‚Äôre pulled in so many directions keeping the organisation going.Randy‚Äôs answer was to ask what I needed from those people and to find out what works. It shifts the onus on to the product manager to create the environment in which governance and communication can happen. While I think that‚Äôs a fair shift to expect working inside a growing organisation, I do think the responsibility is shared: between product people, senior management teams and leadership. We‚Äôre all time-poor, let‚Äôs meet in the middle.Having said that, what do I really need? What clarity can I create?In a way, I have a layered internal communication strategy right now. A fortnightly show & tell for intra-team alignment and feedback; a fortnightly check-in with senior management, for reporting progress and highlighting key developments; and a weekly broadcast weeknote with top-level headlines (awareness-generating and hopefully conversation-starting). If you want to know more from the weeknote or a check-in, there‚Äôs a series of show & tells I can link you to ‚Äì or those can be reformulated into a single narrative. But only the team get the stories, everyone else gets highlights.Is that all they need or want? Maybe that‚Äôs OK.My next contractSomeone reached out with a dream job this week, but I couldn‚Äôt take it because it starts in November and my time with the GOV.‚ÄåUK Design System doesn‚Äôt finish until February. Such a shame!It was pitched just right though: building a value proposition through experimentation and user development, validating and invalidating hypotheses. The intermingling of R&D, experience design, business models and potential.There‚Äôs other work I‚Äôd like to do but please do send over any more like that.This got me thinking about how to advertise myself and what work I‚Äôm capable of doing. Although I‚Äôve been in product management roles for nearly a decade, my skills are more diverse than that.Indeed, the skillset most people have is more diverse than their current role, but it‚Äôs easy to get pigeonholed. There‚Äôs quite a few people on my team who are good at content design, for example, but often we default to asking the content designer to do all content work. That creates bottlenecks. So we should think about skills, not roles.And that‚Äôs how it might be best to advertise myself. Talk about the skills I have, the skills I‚Äôm best at or hired for, and which skills I‚Äôve used on the wide range of projects I‚Äôve worked on.RunningI‚Äôm taking it easy, using one of the 80/20 maintenance plans to maintain fitness. My volume and mileage is right down and it‚Äôs nice to have a rest.A few people have messaged about doing races together after I did the marathon, which has been really nice. I‚Äôve been running alone for 3 years but would love to run with other people. Next weekend I‚Äôm doing a half-marathon with my best mate from home, and before the year is out Kuba wants to run a trail race, so I‚Äôll run one with him.In February I‚Äôm going to run the marathon course again, which will be a totally different experience in the depths of winter as opposed to the highs of summer. Tracking work

This week I completed 25 tasks, although there‚Äôs a few I didn‚Äôt note down. Only 8 unplanned tasks this week. That means most of my time was spent on planned tasks. That matches up with my achievement rate of 87.5% this week ‚Äì I achieved 7 out of 8 weekly goals!

A few weeks ago I set my goals for the month, and I added to that list over the month, so I set 12 goals in total. I achieved 6 of those goals, an achievement rate of 50%, and I progressed 3 goals. So a lot of the work I did this month contributed to the goals I had set for the projects I‚Äôm working on. Nice.

There were 3 goals I didn‚Äôt start but, to be fair, I descoped those based on a roadmap change. So I‚Äôm happy with not getting those done.

Pretty sure I‚Äôm working on the right things. Unplanned work always crops up for product managers, but there was less of it last week. So I‚Äôm still spending the majority of my time on things that move the needle. Pretty happy with the achievement rate of monthly goals too. The high priority stuff got done.

Might calculate how much time I spend on TeamOps, curious to know whether it‚Äôs a big portion of time.

Design System Day 2023

Everything‚Äôs starting to slot in to place with this now. It has been planned in detail and that‚Äôs paying off, all the major priority tasks have been done. We‚Äôve got to do some training on Hopin for the second day of the conference, but that‚Äôll chime nicely with a test run of the plan for both days.

It‚Äôs always the same with running events. Everything seems manic and stressful in the run up, but the planning always pays off. I‚Äôve been reminding the team that we‚Äôve got the major stuff done so the conference is almost already a confirmed success. It‚Äôs still worth reserving a little energy for adapting to last-minute changes on the day though.

I‚Äôm trying not to get too busy on other things so I can be a backstop for any big-effort tasks, but it‚Äôs all going well so far.

Agile governance and communications

At the product community session, I asked Randy a question about tactics for agile governance and communication as organisations scale. Show & tells and blogging filled this purpose at GDS in the early days, but 10 years later things haven‚Äôt really changed.

If anything, the blogging has dried up compared to the early proliferation of many posts per week. There‚Äôs internal weeknotes but these are bullet points that don‚Äôt capture the context or detail of our deep work. And senior management and leadership is too busy to come to show & tells, they‚Äôre pulled in so many directions keeping the organisation going.

Randy‚Äôs answer was to ask what I needed from those people and to find out what works. It shifts the onus on to the product manager to create the environment in which governance and communication can happen. While I think that‚Äôs a fair shift to expect working inside a growing organisation, I do think the responsibility is shared: between product people, senior management teams and leadership. We‚Äôre all time-poor, let‚Äôs meet in the middle.

Having said that, what do I really need? What clarity can I create?

In a way, I have a layered internal communication strategy right now. A fortnightly show & tell for intra-team alignment and feedback; a fortnightly check-in with senior management, for reporting progress and highlighting key developments; and a weekly broadcast weeknote with top-level headlines (awareness-generating and hopefully conversation-starting). If you want to know more from the weeknote or a check-in, there‚Äôs a series of show & tells I can link you to ‚Äì or those can be reformulated into a single narrative. But only the team get the stories, everyone else gets highlights.

Is that all they need or want? Maybe that‚Äôs OK.

My next contract

Someone reached out with a dream job this week, but I couldn‚Äôt take it because it starts in November and my time with the GOV.‚ÄåUK Design System doesn‚Äôt finish until February. Such a shame!

It was pitched just right though: building a value proposition through experimentation and user development, validating and invalidating hypotheses. The intermingling of R&D, experience design, business models and potential.

There‚Äôs other work I‚Äôd like to do but please do send over any more like that.

This got me thinking about how to advertise myself and what work I‚Äôm capable of doing. Although I‚Äôve been in product management roles for nearly a decade, my skills are more diverse than that.

Indeed, the skillset most people have is more diverse than their current role, but it‚Äôs easy to get pigeonholed. There‚Äôs quite a few people on my team who are good at content design, for example, but often we default to asking the content designer to do all content work. That creates bottlenecks. So we should think about skills, not roles.

And that‚Äôs how it might be best to advertise myself. Talk about the skills I have, the skills I‚Äôm best at or hired for, and which skills I‚Äôve used on the wide range of projects I‚Äôve worked on.

Running

I‚Äôm taking it easy, using one of the 80/20 maintenance plans to maintain fitness. My volume and mileage is right down and it‚Äôs nice to have a rest.

A few people have messaged about doing races together after I did the marathon, which has been really nice. I‚Äôve been running alone for 3 years but would love to run with other people. Next weekend I‚Äôm doing a half-marathon with my best mate from home, and before the year is out Kuba wants to run a trail race, so I‚Äôll run one with him.

In February I‚Äôm going to run the marathon course again, which will be a totally different experience in the depths of winter as opposed to the highs of summer. Means I‚Äôve got to start marathon training again next week, but that‚Äôs good: my volume has decreased but the amount I‚Äôm eating hasn‚Äôt, which means my waistline has grown!

Tracking work

Last week I started using Roger‚Äôs system for tracking work and keeping focus so that I could stay on top of tasks, make sure I‚Äôm working towards the right goals, and to introduce feedback loops into working month.

So I held back.Tom followed up with a comment on Slack that was really useful, as it helps articulate the value in using those big numbers. This week I

  • archived a page

Busy week with two full in-person days, which were really enjoyable. Tiring though. Spent most of my time preparing slide decks!

Tracking work

Last week I was just about keeping on top of my work so decided to try Roger‚Äôs system for tracking work and keeping focus this week. How did it go?

I made sure to use the time at the start of each day to plan what I was going to do, which is the main improvement I wanted to make. Success! Tracking my tasks throughout the day was OK, I kept a Notion page open to remind me to fill it in. But I did occasionally forget. Maybe I‚Äôll create an automation that asks me what I‚Äôm doing every 30 mins, a bit like Michael used dot-tracking for. Perhaps it‚Äôs an over-optimisation though, another notification to add to a lifetime full of pings.

In total I completed 17 tasks, most of those were planned but 5 were unplanned tasks that popped up. My achievement rate was 50%, as I achieved 3 of the 6 goals I set for the week. The 3 goals I didn‚Äôt achieve have been bumped to next week, as more important and urgent things came up, and these 3 goals didn‚Äôt need to happen this week. So I‚Äôm pretty happy with that.

It turned out that I didn‚Äôt need to do one of the goals I set myself at all. Having thought there was nothing lined up for our product community session, I pulled together a talk that Tom had asked me to do, but there was already something arranged. My bad: I‚Äôll be more careful with setting myself work to do outside the team.

Feels like a good system so far!

Design system impact

David and I gave a talk at the GDS Get Together on Friday on the subject of impact. Instead of showing a bunch of slides with numbers on, we told the story of how the GOV.‚ÄåUK Design System influences organisations across the UK public sector and globally. And how we focus more on making impact through multiplier effects.

We needed to do a lot of that in the early years, but now we make more impact through multiplier effects: like modernising our conventions on JavaScript, assessing how new accessibility criteria for WCAG 2.2 will affect UI design, updating components and patterns in response, and running community workshops to share knowledge and improve skills across the Civil Service.

And we don‚Äôt just look after a product or service. We‚Äôre part of an active global conversation on how people use the web. We feed back into accessibility working groups and technical specifications, we raise bugs with browser vendors, and we influence many international organisations ‚Äì including W3C‚Äôs design system.

It makes sense having a centralised team doing this at scale, for the benefit of service teams and users. There‚Äôs diminishing returns on us adding more and more components to the design system, so I‚Äôm going to look at how we can better enable our community to do this (and iterate what they add).

Our team‚Äôs best work is at the system level, and there are plenty of teams innovating, creating new components and patterns for the GOV.‚ÄåUK ecosystem. There‚Äôs some work to do in shifting perceptions, as we‚Äôre some times seen as a design authority ‚Äì but our purpose is design enabler.

Anyway, lots of work to do. I‚Äôm shaping a discovery and discussions with teams in the run up to Design System Day, so will have more to say on this later.

In the Before Times, we‚Äôd put posters up on the wall. We‚Äôd huddle around a TV during standup, we‚Äôd stick things on our desks, and we‚Äôd scribble on whiteboards as part of our work. But that all happens inside tools now. Those tools look different for each person on the team, and there‚Äôs no shared front page. The sense of team unity and having a shared space becomes fractured.

So I asked the team what we might do to rekindle that sense of unity in a way that embraces hybrid remote-first working.

There were lots of great ideas including stickers, desktop backgrounds, desk toys, internal blogs and podcasts for team memories, NPC team-mates, and ways to personalise our sanitary, functional project boards.

That last one is a big one. Why are JIRA, GitHub Projects, Linear and other project management solutions so lifeless and devoid of character? With Trello we could add backgrounds to boards, but what about team photos, stickers, posters and other personal items. Bring the fun back to where we work.

I‚Äôm going to join a local running club next week, think I‚Äôm ready to acknowledge this is no longer a temporary get-fit plan, it‚Äôs a big, enjoyable hobby.

This makes it feel less grubby, and there‚Äôs other little rules that help prevent estimation from being misused.Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned so far about estimating software projects. This is a living list that I‚Äôll revisit and add to over time, so let me know if there‚Äôs anything I‚Äôve missed or got wrong.Rules for estimating software projectsThe first rule of estimation is that accurate estimation is an oxymoron. Think in 2-week blocks, not days. Don‚Äòt get in the weeds working out how many hours something will take. Use a broad brush.The second rule is that the process can be more valuable than the output (like roadmapping). Figuring out the stages of a project and the work we need to do is more enlightening than knowing how long it could take, as it allows you to identify essential work you might not have considered. Good communication is more important than good estimation.The third rule is explain how the estimation will be used. It could be that you need to plan releases, or make sure something‚Äòs ready for/before a policy/legislation/regulation deadline, or align with another team‚Äòs work, or work out how much of a bottleneck we‚Äòll have because we don‚Äòt have enough of X role. You never need to know when something will be done for knowing‚Äòs sake, so don‚Äòt hide it from your team-mates. Be honest.The fourth rule is that there are always undiscovered tasks. Until you‚Äòve uncovered all the unknowns, scoped a project (decided what to do now and what to do in later iterations) and made all the big decisions, you‚Äòll never know how much work there truly is to do. Which includes beta stages where you‚Äòre collecting feedback ‚Äì you don‚Äòt know what‚Äòs gonna come up. Timeboxing is better than estimation for discovery and alpha, but once you‚Äòre at the beta building stage, that‚Äòs when estimations are useful.The fifth rule is revisit your estimations regularly. Things change, all the time (including your mood). It‚Äòs also motivating to tick things off and mark them as complete, to step back and see progress made on a big project.The sixth and final rule: never use estimates against people. There are too many external factors that negatively impact our productivity. If something took longer than we thought it might and it‚Äòs a problem, dig into why. Rules for estimating software projects

The first rule of estimation is that accurate estimation is an oxymoron. Think in 2-week blocks, not days. Don‚Äòt get in the weeds working out how many hours something will take. Use a broad brush.

The second rule is that the process can be more valuable than the output (like roadmapping). Figuring out the stages of a project and the work we need to do is more enlightening than knowing how long it could take, as it allows you to identify essential work you might not have considered. Good communication is more important than good estimation.

The third rule is explain how the estimation will be used. It could be that you need to plan releases, or make sure something‚Äòs ready for/before a policy/legislation/regulation deadline, or align with another team‚Äòs work, or work out how much of a bottleneck we‚Äòll have because we don‚Äòt have enough of X role. You never need to know when something will be done for knowing‚Äòs sake, so don‚Äòt hide it from your team-mates. Be honest.

The fourth rule is that there are always undiscovered tasks. Until you‚Äòve uncovered all the unknowns, scoped a project (decided what to do now and what to do in later iterations) and made all the big decisions, you‚Äòll never know how much work there truly is to do. Which includes beta stages where you‚Äòre collecting feedback ‚Äì you don‚Äòt know what‚Äòs gonna come up. Timeboxing is better than estimation for discovery and alpha, but once you‚Äòre at the beta building stage, that‚Äòs when estimations are useful.

The fifth rule is revisit your estimations regularly. Things change, all the time (including your mood). It‚Äòs also motivating to tick things off and mark them as complete, to step back and see progress made on a big project.

The sixth and final rule: never use estimates against people. There are too many external factors that negatively impact our productivity. If something took longer than we thought it might and it‚Äòs a problem, dig into why. Your processes and organisation are probably more to blame than the people doing the work.

Good holiday sailing around the southeastern Spanish coast last week. It wasn‚Äôt as windy as we‚Äôd hoped but we managed to do a few trips out of Cartagena. One highlight was sailing from Cabo de Palos to La Manga, just in time to enter the marina as they raised the bridge for the final time that day. We anchored off of an island in the Mar Menor, a coastal lagoon, for a restful night in nature.

And I need to talk about Restaurante Salzillo in Murcia. It‚Äôs an absolute dream. Chefs work behind a bar, which you can dine at (a bit like Barrafina), and there‚Äôs a large, glass-fronted refrigerator stocked with some of the sweetest prawns and seafood you‚Äôve ever had. Plenty of good Spanish food and wine. I was in heaven. We had clams, octopus, artichokes, John Dory, tuna, and a lovely Albari√±o. My postres was unique: paparajote, a battered lemon leaf dipped in sugar and cinnamon. Very delicate flavours.

This week I was back to work, and amongst many other things I haven‚Äôt noted down, I

  • caught up on a bunch of emails and Slack messages
  • joined an asynchronous research analysis session (super well organised)
  • chatted about the rollout of the new crown
  • joined the usual team ceremonies (show & tell, retro, planning)
  • added expiry dates to our team playbook, so that we keep it up-to-date
  • joined a retro on the recent programme-wide roadmapping process
  • planned some follow-up actions from our recent coaching session
  • collaborated on a presentation for the GDS Get Together next week
  • sought guidance from our designers on what work would be suitable for a new joiner
  • caught up on the planning of Design System Day 2023 (tickets available on Monday!)
  • shared thoughts on what our next coaching session might contain
  • met our new associate delivery manager
  • caught up with our deputy director
  • thought a lot about our future strategy, which needs adding to my notes
  • had a check-in with our senior management team
  • prepared a new system for tracking goals and tasks
  • caught up on the WCAG 2.2 epic and discussed how we might mitigate a bottleneck
  • had a career chat with a product manager from NHS England
  • started refining the thesis of our presentation for the GDS Get Together

Treading water

A couple of times this week I said ‚ÄòI feel like I‚Äôm treading water‚Äô, which means I feel like I‚Äôm just about managing to keep on top of things. Weeknoting is helping by giving me time to reflect on the week, but if I‚Äôm still feeling like too much is going on, something else is amiss. My current theory is that it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm not setting goals and tracking my tasks well enough.

That‚Äôs silly because each morning I have time to set my daily goals, I just don‚Äôt do it. Sure, I block out my calendar for certain tasks and I stash things in Slack reminders for later, but I don‚Äôt know whether all that busyness is laddering up to achieving my main objectives.

So I‚Äôm going to try Roger‚Äôs system for tracking work and keeping focus, it looks like it‚Äôll be a big help.

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs anything to do with being the only product person on a team of 17 people (with two squads). Other teams of a similar size in our programme have more product managers, but I see our lead frontend developer, our community designer and our accessibility specialist as playing a product role too. My job is to tie it all together into a coherent strategy.

Asking for estimates

Asking for estimations of when a project might be complete feels grubby. It shouldn‚Äòt have to, but no one likes it. Heck, when someone asks me for estimations, I know it could be useful but it still feels‚Ä¶off.

My approach usually is to explain how it‚Äòs a useful exercise and how the estimation will be used, but I didn‚Äòt do that a couple of weeks ago. I got uncomfortable and skipped over it, just saying I needed an estimate of when the project might finish, and it irked a colleague. Calling that out as a mistake I made, because there is value in estimation.

I‚Äôve written up some light rules for estimation off the back of this.

Retros as an attack vector

We start each retrospective with the Agile Prime Directive: everyone did their best under the circumstances. That‚Äòs supposed to set the tone, so that people can discuss issues openly, with empathy, to find a solution together. But some times this doesn‚Äòt happen and it can feel like someone‚Äòs complaining about you, right in front of you, without saying explicitly that you‚Äòre the problem.

Sure, you‚Äòre not supposed to make it personal or take it personally. But it‚Äòs hard not to be human.

One guideline I find useful for making feedback constructive instead of critical is to suggest remedial actions or solutions whenever I raise a problem or issue. This thing could have been better, and here‚Äòs a suggestion for how.

There is a time and a place for critical feedback, and it‚Äòs usually in a one-to-one meeting, not in a group setting.

Maybe agreeing some norms around retro hygiene would be good, rather than continuing to rely on the Agile Prime Directive. Its intent is right but when you‚Äòre too familiar with a phrase, it‚Äòs easy to ignore.

First marathon

Tomorrow I‚Äòm running my first marathon. 42km across the Shropshire hills with 1,000m of elevation. My race strategy is quite simple.

Goal: to finish. No time-based goal, but the course limit is 7 hours.

  • Easy-pace the first half
  • Fast-walk the hills
  • Fun-pace the last 10k (plus caffeine)
  • Drink enough
  • 200 cals every 30 mins
  • Most of all, enjoy the landscape!

EDIT: Strategy worked a dream. I could have done with more water, given it was 28-degrees Celsius, but I finished in just over 5 hours and came second place for my first marathon. Chuffed.

Writing these on Wednesday night and I‚Äôll publish them on Thursday night because Friday is holiday time.

This week I

  • caught up with a team answering our call for speakers for Design System Day 2023
  • did a workshop on roles & responsibilities, and one on our contribution & product development model, at a team coaching session
  • picked up a good perspective on what it takes to run the design system from Tom
  • checked in on the team‚Äôs work to update GOV.‚ÄåUK Frontend to be compliant with WCAG 2.2
  • prepped for check-in with our senior management team
  • filled in a data protection impact assessment for a new tool
  • met with the excellent Jess to pick up tips on open source, maintenance and communities at GitHub
  • met with my Strava crush, Tom, to talk about design, data and running
  • met with design evangelists Linda and Mike to learn how they iterate and develop Apple‚Äôs Human Interface Guidelines
  • added a contribution guide to our team playbook
  • updated the roadmap, and
  • joined (or facilitated) the usual fortnightly show & tell, retro and sprint planning ceremonies.

Coaching

Stefan ran a great workshop at the start. The team went over the principles that Imran, Kelly and I set back in April and rated which ones we were doing best at and which ones we had room to grow on. We reviewed the answers as a team and many people thought we could do better on ‚ÄòTransfer power‚Äô, which is fair enough as we‚Äôve only made a dent as a collective.

Everyone thought we were doing well on ‚ÄòProgress, don‚Äôt perfect‚Äô, which initially I wasn‚Äôt sure about. But then Stefan asked us to think about examples or reasons we answered the way we did. And as I thought about it, I realised the team had done a fair bit on that principle recently. Which made me feel bad for not realising it sooner‚Ä¶but I felt great about the progress the team has made.

Next up Kelly ran a workshop we put together on roles and responsibilities. The team have been wanting to know what their roles are, where they fit in, what they should and shouldn‚Äôt do, and we wanted to address that. But I didn‚Äôt want to tell them because I believe they know. So instead, we read through the DDaT profiles for each role and marked down things we knew we were expected to do and things we weren‚Äôt sure about. We went through the ‚ÄòNot sures‚Äô as a team and either clarified a responsibility or put a pin in it, to come back to it later.

After lunch, I ran a workshop on our contribution & product development model and where people fit in. Using our iterated model as a base, I asked each discipline on the team to note down whether they had a driving role, a supporting role, or needed awareness only at each stage of the model. It was pretty much bang on, although there‚Äôs a couple of opportunities to downgrade roles (from supporting to needing awareness) and create some co-driving.

Once that was done, I asked each discipline to note down their top two needs from other disciplines in order to do their job well. I wish we‚Äôd had more time for this as we could only cover the top need, but people were able to sign tacit contracts with each other or ask for more clarity. We must revisit that workshop and nail it down, as it‚Äôs going to make multidisciplinary working so much smoother.

What it takes to run the design system

Right now I‚Äôd say the team is working close to full capacity. Some tweaks to processes will help but it‚Äôs mere optimisation for marginal gains. The GOV.‚ÄåUK Design System is a well-adopted, mature design system ‚Äì it‚Äôs in a great place! ‚Äì hence the demands on our team. But the backlog is years long, we don‚Äôt have time to review and iterate the existing catalogue, and managing the community needs a small team itself.

To scale the Design System to meet the demands placed on it, we‚Äôre going to need to distribute and devolve governance and assurance. And that‚Äôs a big experiment. If it doesn‚Äôt work or it‚Äôs not sustainable, the team will need to grow. Not by many, maybe 3 or 4 people, but that‚Äôs a bigger budget when purse strings are tightening.

Open source, maintenance and communities

Jess is a staff product manager at GitHub and looked after the Sponsorship and Maintainer products until a recent restructure, so I wanted to find out if she‚Äôs come across any best practice with sustaining community contributions for open source software. She had tons of advice, and thankfully a lot of it validated what we‚Äôre already doing.

Documentation needs to be tight, making it clear you want help is a must, and making community contributions sustainable is a decades old problem no one has really solved. But by continuing to believe in and add effort to the cause, we might just crack it one day.

Apple‚Äôs design language is 40 years old, so it was great to get some hunches confirmed (and a few tips to boot) from Mike and Linda on the Human Interface Guidelines team.

There is a paradigm shift in GOV.‚ÄåUK‚Äôs design language soon, from static web-based experiences to dynamic multichannel experiences. The challenge is keeping the look and feel, the brand, consistent while meeting many of the expectations and constraints put on our 10-year-old design language. It‚Äôll happen slowly. Ideally you won‚Äôt realise it‚Äôs happening. Boring magic and that.

We can help make that happen but also we mustn‚Äôt get in the way of teams innovating. So it was helpful to learn from what kind of things work well. Quelle suprise, a strong design community of practice helps maintain consistency, but so can designing new capabilities for our service.

I made many notes in that chat but don‚Äôt have them to hand, so I‚Äôll add them at a later date.

items.title: Bureaucracy, fear, and damaging dogma
items.summary: For all the good that GDS has done, it has also stoked a culture of fear. If we want to innovate government services to make them radically better, we need to address this.
items.content_text: Note: I wrote this back in February 2023 but didn‚Äôt press publish until now. Should have done it sooner.There was a good talk run by UCL‚Äôs Institute for Innovation and Public Purpose towards the end of January that looked at why innovation needs bureaucracy. The event accompanied the launch of a book that looks at ‚Äòagile stability‚Äô: ‚Äúthat in order to successfully innovate, state organisations have to move nimbly like start-ups and yet ensure stability at the same time.‚ÄùAmongst the academic chatter that, to be honest, often went over my head, there were examples shared of what that ‚Äòagile stability‚Äô means. Rules or principles that guide people, which I‚Äôve written about before. Not a playbook or a step-by-step, but some guardrails that keep you on track while giving space for creativity. For innovation.My guess is that that was the intention of the Service Standard. It encourages teams to build services in a user-centred, iterative way. A service assessment then gives teams the opportunity to tell the story of how they utilised those methods.The thing is, despite everyone‚Äôs best efforts to avoid this and reframe service assessments as friendly reviews by digital peers, there is a culture of fear amongst service teams. And I think this stifles creativity and innovation.I‚Äôve been working on the GOV.UK Design System for just shy of 3 months now, and we receive frequent questions about needing ‚Äòsign off‚Äô or ‚Äòapproval‚Äô to do things. For example, if you‚Äôre looking for a date picker to include in your service, the GOV.UK Design System doesn‚Äôt have one. But Digital Scotland does. So we were asked what sign-off was needed to use it.None. You don‚Äôt need any approval.Sure, you‚Äôll get asked about using the design system in alpha and beta assessments, but you don‚Äôt have to. (There are many reasons why you should, but there are reasons why teams don‚Äôt.) And if you haven‚Äôt designed or implemented an accessible component, this will get picked up in an accessibility audit. But so will everything else.What‚Äôs most interesting in this example is that the team asking about sign-off were working on a live service. Digging in to their thought patterns, they realised that there wasn‚Äôt a service assessment or anything similar to go through. They had been worried about being ‚Äòpulled up‚Äô on using a non-GOV.UK component, but realised there wasn‚Äôt a moment when they would be policed on this.This is one example in a pattern of questions about ‚ÄòGDS approved‚Äô ways of doing things. It signals a culture of fear, where people find it hard to do their job for fear of misstepping.Another example: my service owner at NHS Digital was petrified of the alpha service assessment. They thought that if they failed the assessment, the service would be stopped. This caused them to focus more on boxes to tick in order to pass, rather than thinking about what good looked like, what our priorities should be, and how to empower teams to do their best work.This doesn‚Äôt feel good. Constraints should encourage creativity, not stifle it. When people feel they need to tick boxes, they‚Äôre not in the right headspace to innovate. To make government services radically better.We need to address the dogma, otherwise it‚Äôll be damaging in the long-run. For an organisation that professes the benefits of open-working, agility, and co-design, it hasn‚Äôt done too well at creating psychological safety in the system.The bureaucracy got too much. It has its uses, but we need to rebalance it to encourage more agility, more innovation. I don‚Äôt know how just yet ‚Äì others have suggested how to rethink the phases ‚Äì but I‚Äôm sure we can figure it out.
